title: Oversold Conditions For SAP
description: Legendary investor Warren Buffett advises to be fearful when others are greedy, and be greedy when others are fearful.  One way we can try to measure the level of fear in a given stock is through a technical analysis indicator called the Relative Strength Index, or RSI, which me
content:
Legendary investor Warren Buffett advises to be fearful when others are greedy, and be greedy when others are fearful. One way we can try to measure the level of fear in a given stock is through a technical analysis indicator called the Relative Strength Index, or RSI, which measures momentum on a scale of zero to 100. A stock is considered to be oversold if the RSI reading falls below 30.

In trading on Thursday, shares of SAP SE (Symbol: SAP) entered into oversold territory, hitting an RSI reading of 29.3, after changing hands as low as $269.40 per share. By comparison, the current RSI reading of the S&P 500 ETF (SPY) is 54.1. A bullish investor could look at SAP's 29.3 RSI reading today as a sign that the recent heavy selling is in the process of exhausting itself, and begin to look for entry point opportunities on the buy side. The chart below shows the one year performance of SAP shares:

Looking at the chart above, SAP's low point in its 52 week range is $210.38 per share, with $313.28 as the 52 week high point — that compares with a last trade of $269.75.

Find out what 9 other oversold stocks you need to know about »
summary: The Relative Strength Index (RSI) indicator, which measures momentum, indicates a decrease in confidence in a stock that is considered oversold if it falls below 30. The current RSI reading of the S&P 500 ETF is 54.1. This could be seen as a sign that the recent heavy selling is in the process of unworried.
shortSummary: SAPSE shares entered oversold territory, with the RSI index measuring 29.3% below 30,000 points, indicating significant investor concern.

scraped_sources.text:
CMA Dividend Growth Rate
On this page we examine the CMA dividend growth over time, by tabulating the total dividend ex-dates that fall
into each calendar year, and then comparing the year over year totals through time. Each of the CMA dividend growth tables
by year are listed below, and overall, the 1996 to 2024 simple average CMA dividend growth rate = 10.82%,
with the worst CMA dividend growth rate over that time being -91.34% and the best CMA dividend growth rate being 68.81%, as detailed below. Note: because
the method used is to tally all ex-dates within each calendar year, our calculations will also include any "special" dividends that may fall into that year; investors
should note that this will produce a different result than if only comparing "regular" dividend growth rate during those periods.

argos_summary: Warren Buffett’s classic market‑timing rule—be fearful when others are greedy and greedy when others are fearful—is illustrated with the Relative Strength Index (RSI), where a reading below 30 signals an oversold condition; SAP shares fell into this zone with an RSI of 29.3, suggesting a potential buying opportunity. The article also presents an extensive historical record of CMA dividend growth, showing an average 10.82% increase from 1996‑2024, with recent years (2023‑24) flat at 0% and earlier periods ranging from steep gains to sharp declines. The data highlight the volatility of dividend performance over time and provide a benchmark for evaluating current payouts.
